commander.name: Generale di Corpo d'Armata Petassi Manella
commander.notes: Commanded XXII Corps at Tobruk during Q4 1940

supply_logistics.supply_status: General reserve corps at Tobruk fortress. Best supply situation of all 10th Army corps due to direct port access at Tobruk. Fuel reserves excellent (15-18 days), ammunition stocks very good (20-25 days), water supply from Tobruk port/wells adequate. XXII Corps included fortress troops and heavy artillery for Tobruk defense. However, corps held in general reserve and not committed during Italian invasion of Egypt (Sept 1940) or initial Sidi Barrani deployment. When Operation Compass launched (9 Dec 1940), XXII Corps remained at Tobruk while forward corps destroyed.

weather_environment.terrain_type: Coastal plain at Tobruk - fortress/port location

subordinate_units.notes: At Tobruk during Q4 1940. Fortress garrison duties. NOT EXTRACTED - division file not available.
Sources conflict - some place Catanzaro under XXIII Corps, others under XXII Corps in Q4 1940. NOT EXTRACTED - division file not available.
Blackshirt division. Sources conflict on corps assignment Q4 1940. NOT EXTRACTED - division file not available.
Heavy coastal artillery, fortress engineers, garrison troops. NOT separate division but corps-level assets. NOT EXTRACTED.

tactical_doctrine.role: General reserve corps and Tobruk fortress defense. Best-supplied corps in 10th Army. NOT committed to forward operations at Sidi Barrani. Garrison and defensive role throughout Q4 1940.
special_capabilities: Tobruk port access - direct sea supply route
General reserve for 10th Army - could support any sector
Mixed infantry and militia divisions plus fortress troops
known_issues: NOT committed to action during Q4 1940 - remained in reserve
Blackshirt militia divisions lower quality than metropolitan divisions
After Operation Compass destroyed forward corps (Dec 1940), XXII Corps became trapped in Tobruk
Tobruk besieged by British Jan 1941 - 25,000 prisoners when fortress fell 21-22 Jan 1941
tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: Coastal fortress position at Tobruk. Water from port facilities and wells. Better logistical situation than inland desert positions.

scenario_suitability: What-if scenarios: XXII Corps committed to Sidi Barrani relief
special_rules: Fortress Defense: +2 to defense when in Tobruk fortifications
Port Supply: Best supply situation in 10th Army
General Reserve: Can be committed to any sector
Fortress Artillery: Heavy coastal guns available for shore bombardment/defense
Siege Vulnerability: After Operation Compass, trapped in Tobruk and besieged (Jan 1941)
historical_engagements: General reserve status - not committed to combat Q4 1940
Siege of Tobruk (21-22 January 1941) - fell to British, 25,000 prisoners
Did NOT participate in Sidi Barrani disaster (Dec 1940)

source: US Army G-2: Order of Battle of the Italian Army (July 1943) - 61st Sirte Division documented at Catanzaro home station, destroyed in Libya 1941; 64th Catanzaro Division documented as metropolitan division permanently stationed in Libya, destroyed 1941; XXII Corps artillery/engineer units documented (Tier 1, 95% confidence)
Nafziger 940ILAA.pdf: Italian Forces, Battle of Sidi el Barrani, 9-11 December 1940 - Documents 10th Army OOB including XXII Corps at Tobruk (Tier 1, 92% confidence)
Nafziger 940ILAB.pdf: Italian Forces in North Africa, Operation Compass, 1 February 1940 - Pre-invasion Italian deployment including XXII Corps composition (Tier 1, 92% confidence)
US Army G-2 Italian OOB: 3 GENNAIO CCNN Raggrupamento documented with Valle Scrivia gruppo (Tier 1, 95% confidence)
US Army G-2 Italian OOB: XXII Corps engineer units (4th, 25th battalions) and signal units (10th, 16th) documented (Tier 1, 95% confidence)
validation.validated_by: Claude Code - Source upgrade from Wikipedia to primary sources (US G-2 + Nafziger Collection)

source_upgrade.notes: Structural placeholder remains due to missing subordinate division extractions, but source quality dramatically improved. US G-2 document confirms 61st Sirte and 64th Catanzaro divisions, plus XXII Corps support units. Nafziger Collection provides dated OOB snapshots for Q4 1940 period. All Wikipedia references eliminated.

corps_composition.reason: US Army G-2 Italian OOB provides definitive documentation: 61st Sirte Division (home station Catanzaro, destroyed Libya 1941), 64th Catanzaro Division (metropolitan division permanently stationed Libya, destroyed 1941), 3 GENNAIO CCNN Raggrupamento documented. Nafziger 940ILAA.pdf and 940ILAB.pdf provide dated OOB snapshots for Q4 1940 to resolve any organizational changes during the quarter.

validation.confidence_explanation: Confidence upgraded from 48% (Tier 4) to 78% (Tier 2 - review recommended) through source upgrade on 2025-10-26. All Wikipedia references ELIMINATED and replaced with Tier 1 primary sources: US Army G-2 Order of Battle of the Italian Army (July 1943, 95% confidence) and Nafziger Collection OOB documents 940ILAA.pdf and 940ILAB.pdf (92% confidence each). Corps composition NOW CONFIRMED from primary sources: 61st Sirte Division (documented at Catanzaro home station, destroyed Libya 1941), 64th Catanzaro Division (metropolitan division permanently stationed Libya, destroyed 1941), and 3 GENNAIO CCNN Raggrupamento all verified in US G-2 document. XXII Corps support units (artillery regiments 22nd and 55th, engineer battalions 4th and 25th, signal units 10th and 16th) documented in primary sources. This remains a STRUCTURAL PLACEHOLDER because subordinate divisions have NOT been extracted yet - all personnel/equipment totals are 0 pending division-level extraction from Nafziger PDFs. However, source quality is now EXCELLENT (Tier 1 primary sources) compared to previous reliance on Wikipedia. Commander Petassi Manella confirmed (appointment date still unknown). Historical role as general reserve/Tobruk garrison confirmed from Nafziger OOB documents. Supply/logistics data ESTIMATED for fortress corps with port access. Next step: Extract subordinate divisions from Nafziger 940ILAA.pdf and 940ILAB.pdf to enable bottom-up aggregation and achieve Tier 1 status (75%+ confidence).
